body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. PAUL T. MITCHELL Mentor to Many In every firehouse in New York, somebody like Paul T. Mitchell takes the probies under his wing, nurturing them and giving them just enough grief to make sure they can endure. In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, at the Tillary Street
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIMS; New Guys' Teacher, Anticipatory Father and a Family Ringleader

body: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday on six counts of rape and one count of assault in a string of attacks on seven women, the police said last night. The women, ranging in age from 16 to 21, were threatened with a knife and forced to rooftop landings, where they were raped, sodomized, robbed, or, in one case, stabbed in the leg,
title: Man Arrested in String of Rapes in Brooklyn

author: Michael Miscione is a contributor to ''City Secrets: New York City,'' to be published in June by the Little Bookroom. He lives in Turtle Bay.
body: SOON after the Sept. 11 attacks, much was made of an overripe bronze sculpture that a well-meaning company in Pittsburgh donated in tribute to New York's fallen firefighters. It stands on Eighth Avenue near 44th Street. Few New Yorkers realized that we already had our own Firemen's Memorial, a dignified stone and metal monument -- with a separate
title: SOAPBOX; The Forgotten

body: In many ways, the New York City Opera finds itself in an enviable position these days. Perennially overshadowed by the Metropolitan Opera, its own future is now the center of attention in the debate about Lincoln Center's proposed $1.2 billion redevelopment plan. While its hopes for a new home on the Lincoln Center campus appear to have been
title: To Stay or Go? City Opera Is Deciding on Its Home

body: Drawing Dickens Accounts of harsh working conditions for children and lack of education for the poor were Charles Dickens's inspiration for ''A Christmas Carol,'' written in less than two months in 1843. And successive generations have emphasized different social and cultural aspects: traditional Christmas festivities, Scrooge's transformation,
title: Footlights

body: RACISM. Gun violence. Police brutality. The work of the artists Bradley McCallum and Jacqueline Tarry charges headlong into provocative territory. That their public art projects in Connecticut and elsewhere ignite response is perhaps typical of contemporary artists. But with their recent effort, in New Haven, they are seeking to fold that reaction
title: ART; Artists of Church Installation Welcome the Controversy

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIMS; Giggling Falls Silent, And Fountains Are Dry: 'My Everything' Is Gone

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: What is the sound of one hand chatting? Mark Hansen and Ben Rubin can answer this Zen-like riddle. For ''Listening Post,'' their new artwork at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, they are monitoring the live activity in thousands of Internet chat rooms and message boards, then converting these public conversations into a computer-generated opera. For
title: ARTS ONLINE; Making an Opera From Cyberspace's Tower of Babel

body: On a rain-soaked evening in 1937, a 9-year-old girl is hit by a car as she crosses the street, returning home from Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn. The impact knocks her unconscious. The driver brings her to the street in front of a nearby hospital. As the car speeds away, the girl, drifting in and out of consciousness, catches just two digits of its
title: The Neediest Cases; Injury from 1937 Accident Confines Woman to Home

body: Two men accused by the police of being the getaway driver and a gunman in a series of shootings in Brooklyn that killed two men and wounded two others, were arraigned yesterday on murder charges. The shootings occurred on Wednesday afternoon at the Raymond V. Ingersoll public housing complex in Fort Greene. A group of friends were in front of a
title: Murder Arraignments for Two Accused in Brooklyn Shooting

body: Shootings that started in a public housing complex and spilled into the streets of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, left two men dead and three others wounded yesterday afternoon, the police said. The shootings were apparently in retaliation for the killing of a man on Sunday, said Detective Madelyne Galindo, a police spokeswoman. Two men were being
title: 2 Are Killed and 3 Are Hurt by Gunfire in Brooklyn

body: As has become increasingly clear in recent years, great dining in New York City isn't limited to Manhattan. The Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island all offer their share of interesting restaurants. Here are eight: AESOP'S TABLES * [Rating: one star] (718) 720-2005; 1233 Bay Street (Maryland Avenue); Rosebank, Staten Island; $$; Review:

body: The past never stopped singing in the fevered brain of Edgar Allan Poe, always chanting on about things lost, things dead, the women (starting with Mother, who died when he was 3) who got away. So it seems fitting that in the midst of ''POEtry,'' a disjointed gray mass of a celebration by the rocker Lou Reed, a classic song from Mr. Reed's own past
title: THEATER REVIEW; Lou Reed, Exploring Poe's Plutonian Shore

title: CABARET GUIDE

body: 'Greed,' Reconstructed One theme of Thanksgiving is gluttony. But after the shopping sprees tomorrow, another deadly sin deserves a say, and the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, is happy to comply. ''Greed,'' a 1924 film by Erich von Stroheim, will be shown there on Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m. in a reconstructed version.
title: Footlights

body: One incoming Council member is a former deputy superintendent of banking for the state. Another is a former member of the Black Panther Party who now runs a leadership-training consulting group. One is a podiatrist, two have served as police officers and still another made a name for himself by organizing an international student exchange program.
title: New City Council a Portrait Composed by Term Limits

author: Jacob Weisberg, chief political correspondent for Slate, is a frequent contributor to the magazine.
body: Dealing with what happened to our city on Sept. 11 has involved a kind of progression, and for many of us, the initial phase included some level of incomprehension. One of the stranger images left in my head from that terrible morning is of a woman standing on my corner in TriBeCa, laughing into her cellphone. Survivors, many of them coated head to
title: The Return Of New York

body: A significant defection of Hispanic voters from the Democratic Party, coupled with stronger-than-expected showings among black voters and white liberals, helped propel Michael R. Bloomberg to victory in the mayoral election over Mark Green, according to a statistical analysis of the voting patterns in Tuesday's election. While Mr. Bloomberg's base
title: Gains Among Hispanic, Black and Liberal Voters Helped Push Bloomberg to Victory

body: Fred Ho's ''Once Upon a Time in Chinese America,'' performed on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater, unspooled to one of the best dance scores to be heard in these parts in recent times. Composed by Mr. Ho and performed live by his Afro-Asian Music Ensemble, the music was brash yet densely textured and full of witty musical
title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; Of Old-Time Treachery With Modern Precepts

body: HOW often is it that a New Yorker gets a chance to work in a charming old building that looks like a medieval fortress, and from an office window, can hear sea lions barking for their chow three times a day? David Rivel is in this fanciful situation. He's the new executive director of the City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that raises money
title: PUBLIC LIVES; From a Room With a View, Going to Bat for Parks

body: NICHOLAS EVANS-CATO has been painting pictures of the same triangle of dirt for five years. Today the object of his affection -- an awkward lot at Hudson Avenue and Front Street in the Vinegar Hill section of Brooklyn -- is filled with sickly grass, robust weeds, automobiles, old socks and a deflated Wilson football. But 200 years ago, historians
title: CITYPEOPLE; A Patch of Dirt With a Haunting Past

body: To the Editor: Felicia Lee describes many of the reasons I love living here, the most important being ''because there are enough people here who try to get along, who try to understand one another.'' I want to thank her for reminding me why I love New York and why, as I think about the future, I hope to someday have a child who is a native New
title: What to Tell a Child

In fact, those who harbor expectations of any theatrical conventions at all would do well to abandon them before buying a ticket, lest the
title: THEATER REVIEW; When Shakespeare Could Use a Warning Label

Kate Burns Ottavino listened intently to a discussion on the composition of the ash that is coating
title: A Curriculum Bent by the Prism of Preservation

body: Bangarra Dance Theater is a modern-dance troupe unlike any other. Its members have been trained in several dance techniques. But what makes the group special is that its works are inspired by the cultural traditions of Australian Aborigines. The company's ability to blend old and new was excitingly demonstrated when it presented ''Corroboree'' on
title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; Traditions From Australia Face Contemporary Life

Wotton, disappeared in the attacks on Sept. 11, and their son, Rodney Patrick, was born eight days later. ''It's like death
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; Fatherless Newborns, an Artist and a Cheerleader in the Face of Cancer

body: As an African-American and a student of history, Sefu Solace said, he knew too much to trust the government fully. But then came the threat of anthrax terror. title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MOOD; Vigilance Is Personal When Threat Is Invisible

body: Take in ''The Theft of Sita,'' a shadow-puppet saga being performed this weekend at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and you'll be impressed at how expressive a drama in two dimensions can be. You'll also probably be glad that three-dimensional work is the norm these days. The piece, part of the Next Wave Down Under Festival, is
title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; A Tale Told by Shadows Blends the Old and the New

body: Board of Education officials said yesterday that they were at a loss to explain why dozens of students and teachers at Stuyvesant High School had experienced headaches and breathing problems since returning last week to the building, which is four blocks north of the collapsed World Trade Center. At a news conference at the board's headquarters,
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SCHOOLS; Unexplained Ailments at Stuyvesant High

title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; A Wind Scatters Dancers And Gathers Them Back

title: Footlights

Harvey Lichtenstein, chairman of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Local Development Corporation,
title: Brooklyn Projects' Sponsors Worry About City Cutbacks

body: Chunky Move is a cheeky troupe. This Australian modern-dance company from Melbourne brought blasts of choreographic excitement to the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater on Wednesday night when it appeared as part of the 2001 Next Wave Festival. The evening offered two works by Gideon Obarzanek, the director of the six-member company. Both
title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; Tangling and Untangling, It's Awkwardness as Art

body: Challenging traditional thinking about political participation in New York City, the gap between white and Hispanic turnout narrowed in the mayoral primary election two weeks ago, a new analysis of voting patterns has shown. In City Council districts that are largely made up of whites of non-Hispanic descent, voter turnout was among the highest in
title: Hispanics Near Whites in Voter Turnout, Study Says

body: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a crew of black and Latino teenage boys say they can no longer think of the police as enemies. Since Sept. 11, the boys say, the officers who patrol their neighborhoods, most of whom are white, no longer eye them with suspicion. Several Haitian-American groups, which had angrily protested police abuse in recent years, have
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: RELATIONS; Sept. 11 Attack Narrows the Racial Divide

body: Neha Patel was still a block away from Stuyvesant High School, but she could no longer hold back the tears. Casting furtive glances at the skyline where the twin towers of the World Trade Center should have been -- and where they were the last time she took her familiar route to school -- she broke down. ''I still don't think it happened,'' Neha
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SCHOOLS; Students Return, Taking Small Steps

body: When 3,000 students return to Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan today for the first time since Sept. 11, any hope of avoiding tangible reminders of the World Trade Center disaster is likely to fade as they cross the Tribeca Bridge, which spans the West Side Highway and empties into the school's second floor. To the south, a half-dozen
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SCHOOLS; Students Set to Return To Stuyvesant Near Ruins

title: What's Doing Around Town

title: Fort Greene Journal; A Godsend in the Guise of a Ball Field

body: Australia is our distant, down-the-rabbit-hole cousin, a nation that is vaguely the geographical size and shape of our own, where they speak the same language (more or less), worship the gods of capitalism and democracy, cope with racial inequities and economic disparity, generally have the freedom and wherewithal to laugh at themselves and hold to
title: THEATER REVIEW; Australia Growing Up, But in a Warped Mirror

body: The boxes in the Thurgood Marshall Democratic Club in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, sat ready to be discarded this past weekend. One was filled with the campaign literature of Alan G. Hevesi. The other contained fliers for Jeannette Gadson, who lost the party's nomination for Brooklyn borough president. ''We've got no use for these any more,'' said
title: For Brooklyn Democrat, A Bad (Election) Day

author: Gia Kourlas is the dance editor of Time Out New York.
body: MODERN dance has experienced a resurgence in a seemingly incongruous place -- the nightclub. The hugely popular ''Lisa LeAnn and Terry Dean Put on a Dance Show,'' for instance, presents experimental choreography once a month at the Galapagos Art and Performance Space, a club in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Organized by two veterans of
title: Dance; A New Stage for Modernists: the Nightclub

body: ALLAN WEXLER, architect and conceptual artist, moved to New York in 1973, just as the World Trade Center was being completed. At the time, the twin towers were controversial among architects and urban critics, many of whom objected to the oversize, blocky structures that had so radically altered the skyline. But Mr. Wexler admired the buildings,
title: REVERBERATIONS; An Inspiration Lives On in His Mind

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Meeting God: Elements of Hindu Devotion'' explores Hinduism's rituals, prayers, customs and festivals in India through more than 75 photographs, devotional objects and videos. Accompanying the exhibition are color photographs by Steve McCurry
title: SPARE TIMES

body: As the face of the next City Council began to take shape with the unofficial results from Tuesday's rescheduled primary election, it became clear that several of the races remained too close to call and were likely to remain that way for several days, if not weeks. In part, the closeness of some of those contests can be attributed to the crowded
title: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: THE CITY COUNCIL; Several Council Races Are Undecided, and May Take a While to Call

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: Barbara Corcoran, the powerhouse Manhattan real estate broker, agreed yesterday to sell the firm she founded, the Corcoran Group, Manhattan's second-largest independent residential real estate company. The buyer is a real estate company jointly owned by the franchising conglomerate Cendant Corporation and the private investment firm Apollo
title: Corcoran Sells Realty Firm She Founded

body: Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn has hills that look out on Lower Manhattan. On the morning of Sept. 11, people were staked out in small groups, strangers trading misinformation and speculation. What was sure and known was that the towers were burning; we could see that from the northern slope of the park. The trees at the edge below us obscure all but
title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Image

body: For hundreds of candidates running for offices throughout New York City, the days since the World Trade Center attack have been fraught with uncertainty. With the election postponed and the city gripped by grief and sorrow, campaigning effectively came to a standstill. But with a citywide election coming on Tuesday, with a primary for mayor and
title: Treading Gingerly on the Campaign Trail

body: Connie Desarden had just begun letting her daughter, Anjoli, 14, ride the subway alone -- and only for the short trip from their East Village home to Stuyvesant High School. But yesterday, in the wake of the World Trade Center attack that closed Stuyvesant indefinitely, Ms. Desarden insisted on escorting Anjoli across the river to Brooklyn
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: STUYVESANT HIGH SCHOOL; Studies Are Resumed Across the East River

body: With parents wondering where students displaced by this week's terror attack would end up, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced yesterday that Stuyvesant High School's 3,000 students would move across the river to Brooklyn Technical High School and that several thousand other students would be dispersed to schools around Manhattan. The
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE SCHOOLS; Stuyvesant High Students To Attend Brooklyn Tech

body: Broadway theaters are to open again today. The League of American Theaters and Producers, the trade organization for Broadway, encouraged ticketholders to exchange tickets for canceled performances for another date by bringing them to the box office. Refunds will also be available on presentation of tickets. Most nationally touring productions will
title: Reopenings and Postponements

body: The official opening was not scheduled until this week, but the dazzling new Mark Morris Dance Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is already up and running. Its dance classes -- for children and adults -- filled up in less than a week, and its available studios have been snapped up by dance companies looking for affordable work space. And as the
title: Mark Morris Dance Center Adds Luster To Brooklyn

body: An article on Friday about gentrification in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, misstated the surname of a nurse who lives in a house her parents bought in 1953. She is Gail Peterson; Fields is the name of her daughter Tanyika.

body: Thirty years ago, the elevated train was removed from Myrtle Avenue in Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, lifting a long, dark shadow from the troubled thoroughfare. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE/CLINTON HILL; New Lamps Where El Once Cast a Shadow

body: On a recent sweet summer evening on a sidewalk in Brooklyn, two acquaintances, middle-class black men approaching 40, got to talking. The conversation turned, as it often does in Fort Greene, to the three R's: race, riches and real estate. They played the license-plate game. ''Look at these cars,'' said Dezo El, pointing at the sedans and S.U.V.'s
title: In Fort Greene, Prosperity Is Bittersweet; Some Blacks Reap Profits As Others Lament Change

body: Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: This was to be the year of the level playing field in New York City politics. Term limits would loosen the grip of incumbency, throwing open the gates to an unprecedented number of contenders for public office. Public financing would reduce the power of money by giving candidates $4 for each $1 they raised. But in the races for City Council, it has
title: PUBLIC FUNDS LAG IN COUNCIL RACES

body: What does Angela Yurman know about the Battle of Brooklyn? ''Just living in Brooklyn is a battle every day,'' she says. In fact, Mrs. Yurman, 59, is well aware that she has been surrounded by ghosts of the battle her entire life. She grew up across the street from the Old Stone House on the edge of Park Slope, a reconstruction of a 1699 Dutch
title: Washington Fought Here; Who Knew?; On 225th Anniversary, Battle of Brooklyn Is Little-Known Chapter

title: A Mixed Field for a Mixed District Expected to Gain in Political Strength

body: To the Editor: Thanks for your article on the Kensington section of Brooklyn [Aug. 5]. We bought one of those huge co-ops on Ocean Parkway just about six months ago. Before this we rented for about a decade, first in Park Slope, then Clinton Hill, then Fort Greene. Not only was the purchase of our current two-bedroom apartment the best investment
title: The Happy Life In Kensington

body: ''Brooklyn Babylon'' begins with some pointed intercutting between a Jamaican rap band in rehearsal and a Hasidic wedding in ecstatic progress. title: FILM REVIEW; Hip-Hop Romeo, Hasidic Juliet

body: The difficulty in reviewing a Chocolate Genius performance comes in trying to choose the peaks. Marc Anthony Thompson, the man behind the persona and the band, may be the most entertaining showman currently working the New York stage. Take such praise as exaggeration, but hyperbole is the only form of rhetoric that suits this unusual artist. On
title: POP REVIEW; The Singer Seems Cheery, Even if His Songs Are Not

body: Adventure-Bound His name is Kirikou, and his tiny village in Africa has been placed under a terrible curse by the sorceress Karaba. So, to the accompaniment of a soundtrack by the Senegalese musician Youssou N'Dour, little Kirikou sets out on a quest to free his village from the curse and learn the secret of Karaba's wickedness. This story is told
title: Footlights

body: DON'T you love it right after the rain?'' Elizabeth Barlow Rogers asked, pointing delightedly at a pair of ducks as she walked through Central Park one misty morning. ''Look! Mr. and Mrs. Mallard!'' Ms. Rogers not only knows almost every inch of the park, but loves it as if she were its mother. Many are glad she does, crediting her with its revival
title: Street Fighter

body: One Council race in the Bronx bristles with nothing less than a longstanding feud between a political machine and a borough dynasty. A contest in Brooklyn is shot through with passionate charges of nepotism over the Council seat held for nearly 20 years by a candidate's mother. In Queens, the Democratic Party organization's prestige is on the line
title: Races for Council Reveal Shifts In Demographics of City Politics

body: For years, the South Oxford Tennis Club cheated death in Houdini-like fashion, surviving demolition orders and 11 eviction notices as an extensive urban renewal project was built around it. The 12th notice finally succeeded, and in December 1997 the city closed the club, which had four clay tennis courts but was primarily a social hall where
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Game, Set and Match for Tennis Club

body: A survey of home sales in what were among the city's most desolate neighborhoods indicates that new construction and renovation of existing housing through city-subsidized programs that promote homeownership significantly increased property values on neighboring blocks. The study of more than 234,000 home sales was commissioned by the Fannie Mae
title: City Homeownership Plans Lift Neighborhoods, Study Says

body: WHAT is outdoor sculpture? Judging from the array of art on the streets, in the parks and plazas and at other locations in New York this summer, what isn't? Since the advent of Earthworks, Process Art and Conceptual Art in the early 1970's, outdoor sculpture has been a constantly expanding territory, and this year its borders seem more far-flung
title: ART REVIEW; Creativity Overhead, Underfoot And Even In the Air

body: NEWS Sinful A night of lust and gluttony beckons this evening. Sloth, envy, greed, pride and anger are promised, too. title: Footlights

body: LAST Fourth of July, the day throngs of spectators flocked to the New York waterfront to watch giant ships glide in from around the world, 200 white-clad sailors and 400 civilians caroused on the roof of a building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard overlooking the docks. Some twirled dance partners to a swing band. Others feasted on strawberries and
title: Yard Work

title: When New Homes Drive Out Old Jobs

body: On his first foray to a predominantly black church in New York City, Michael R. title: In Churches, Candidates Call For Black Voters to Respond

body: IF Yamani Sekhri, who received her M.B.A. from Indiana University in May, had been searching for an apartment in Manhattan a year ago, Michael Shapot would have had one listing, maybe two, to show her on any given day. But this year is different. Ms. Sekhri, who began as an investment banking associate with UBS Warburg in May, phoned Mr. Shapot, an
title: For Class of 2001, a Less Frenetic Market

body: Valmont -- that cold-hearted, handsome devil of a French aristocrat -- wears a flowing white dress to act the part of his most recent sexual conquest. title: THEATER REVIEW; A Fast Way to Live a Classic, But a Slow Way to Die in It

The 703-page work, which is appearing seven months after Lindsay's death, is a
title: ON THE TOWN; 'Fun City' Era: The Lindsay Years

title: THEATER REVIEW; Strindberg's Eerie World Of Lost Souls

body: WITH a sharing spirit uncommon among spoiled and neurotic young royals, Prince Hamlet has invited you to step directly inside his mind and take a close look at what's really going on there. And if you're any kind of lover of theater, you would be mad indeed not to take him up on it before he leaves the Brooklyn Academy of Music after tomorrow
title: THEATER REVIEW; The Prince In Us All

body: Walking into a space designed by James Casebere can be an unsettling experience. Mr. Casebere has based his architectural work on the Berlin sewer system, West African slave quarters, maximum-security prisons and Jefferson's Monticello (by design, Mr. Casebere's Monticello is ankle-deep in water). That is, if you could walk into these spaces. Mr.
title: An Artist's Novel Take on History: He Lets the Walls Talk

body: Elwood City Visits New York In most children's alphabet books, A stands for something simple, like apple. But to fans of the author and illustrator Marc Brown, A is associated with an image that is both more exotic and just as comfortingly familiar: that of Arthur, an 8-year-old who happens to be an aardvark. body: ON a dazzling spring afternoon, Andres Serrano sat in the dark, still living room of his East Village apartment waiting for his visitor's eyes to adjust to the light. title: AT HOME WITH: ANDRES SERRANO; Fitting Out a Triplex Cloister

body: In a setback for a budding arts enclave in Brooklyn, the choreographer Twyla Tharp has abruptly backed out of a plan to open her first permanent dance studio in a Civil War-era church a few blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Workmen were in the midst of renovating the cavernous Gothic-style Sunday school hall inside the Lafayette Avenue
title: Tharp Cancels Plan for Brooklyn Studio

body: The Atlantic Telecom Center in Brooklyn has signed the largest least at a so-called telecommunications hotel in the city with Williams Communications, a broadband network company based in Tulsa, Okla., center officials announced yesterday. The company is taking 169,000 square feet in the telecommunications center, which is scheduled to open later

body: A construction worker slipped off the Williamsburg Bridge and plunged 200 feet into the East River yesterday morning, prompting a daring rescue by two paramedics whom the Fire Department hailed as heroes for their quick thinking. The worker, Dennis Blinn, 37, was in stable condition last night at Bellevue Hospital Center, officials said. The
title: Worker Pulled From East River After Falling From Bridge

body: THE name conjures up images of peaceful 19th-century residential streets, which in many ways are still present. title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cobble Hill; A Landmark Area With a Family Bent

body: Alexander Elegudin, the quarterback for Brooklyn Technical High School, dreads practice. He and his teammates must travel 30 minutes by subway to a public site in Midwood because their school does not have its own athletic field. ''We practice on dirt and play on grass,'' Mr. Elegudin said. ''They've been talking about a home field for 20 years.''
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; It Took 78 Years, but Brooklyn Tech Is Finally Getting a Field

body: It's no Empire State Building or Statue of Liberty, and that is the idea. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT; Dancing Along A Path Unbeaten By Most Tourists

body: And now, newly imported from Paris, France, here's the very latest model of ''Hamlet.'' title: THEATER REVIEW; Sweet Prince, You're a Scamp

body: The screams and wails mingled with shouts of Jesus' name, echoing from inside the brick walls of a former toy factory in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
